I like your idea of using OPTIONS, but it does seem to be a retrofit to its=
 intended purpose of probing HTTP servers (and proxies) for their supported=
 methods, types, protocol version, etc.  Using HEAD to obtain a service's m=
etadata seems a better match to the methods definition, although head is me=
ant to get the metadata for a GET against the service's URI, not a POST.  I=
n other words, OPTIONS seems to be for obtaining more communications-centri=
c metadata, while HEAD seems to be for obtaining more content-centric metad=
ata.

// see: http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec9.html#sec9.4
=

How about evaluating these approaches against a specific, theoretical scen=
ario?  Suppose we have a service that supplies weather reports given a spec=
ific location.  Clients can currently specify the location by zip code or c=
ity+state, although it will soon support latitude+longitude too.  The servi=
ce can provide the response weather report as either text/html, application=
/xhtml+xml, text/vnd.wap.wml, text/xml, and even image/gif...the client nee=
d only specify which it wants via ACCEPT.  The service has a name, descript=
ion, version, author, and links to reviews.  The reviews are in fact other =
services provided by Amazon, epinions, etc. that can be accessed both progr=
ammatically and interactively.  The service currently supports the USA and =
Canada, but will soon support much of Western Europe too.

Now I, a user, w=
ant to find out about this service.  How do I do it, given only a URL a fri=
end sent me of http://host.domain.tld/services/free/?svc=3Dweather&zip=3D98=
005

> There must be a way to get to a service's metadata given

 the service's URI. 

You could just call HEAD and no entity would be retur=
ned.

Still, this is part of the reason why I've suggested
that the OPTIONS=
 method could be used for this 
purpose.  There wouldn't have to be the "ex=
pense" of
an extra header with each GET, but there are trade
offs with usin=
g this approach (like firewall restrictions
etc., and the adoption of a sta=
ndard but obscure method)

[This paraphrases a message I posted to distribu=
ted-registry]

While the Allow: header could be returned in any
response, i=
t is normally only returned in response
to an OPTIONS method.  From one per=
spective this
describes a refinement of a resources interface:

	Allow: GET=
,PUT,POST,DELETE  being analogous to:

	interface resource {
		delete();
		=
representation get();
		put(representation r);
		post(representation r);
	}=


		vs. 

	Allow: GET,POST  being analogous to:

	interface resource {
		re=
presentation get();
		post(representation r);
	}

From this perspective, th=
e OPTIONS method is already supplying
a form of metadata; using it to give =
the Meta-Location: header
would seem to be a natural extension to this "fun=
ctionality."
